page.title: 03LOCAL HISTORY - 2
page.content: The resident vicar of St Mary's was the Reverend Gabb, who came in the 1830s and stayed for 41 years. Churchyard extension in 1855 accommodated graves of Indian Civil Servants, naval men and the Irish of whom there were a large local population at the time. Parish possessions include an old font, two coats of arms, an oak parish chest dating from the time of the Crusades, a peal of bells and a Victorian pulpit and lectern. 19th century church schools included one for girls and the Higgs Charity which accepted six boys to study for three years. The Higgs Charity still exists as a local educational trust, known as the Higgs- Cooper Charity, which gives grants to local schools for a wide range of activities.
